column3: DEE-KAB) is located in the north central portion of the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census
column6: making it Georgia's fourth-most populous county. Its county seat is Decatur.DeKalb County is included in the Atlanta-Sandy Springs-Roswell
column7: GA Metropolitan Statistical Area. It contains roughly 10% of the city of Atlanta (the other 90% lies in Fulton County). It is Georgia's most diverse county. DeKalb is a primarily a suburban county.

column2: DeKalb earned the Atlanta Regional Commission's "Green Communities" designation for its efforts in conserving energy
column3: water and fuel; investing in renewable energy; reducing waste; and protecting and restoring natural resources.

column2: some communities in North DeKalb have incorporated
column3: following a trend in other suburban areas around Metro Atlanta. Dunwoody and Brookhaven are now the largest cities entirely within the county.

column2: formed in 1822 from Henry
column3: Gwinnett and Fayette counties
column4: took its name from Baron Johann de Kalb (1721-1780)
column5: a Bavarian-born former officer in the French Army
column6: who fought for the Continental Army in the American Revolutionary War. The oldest existing house in the county is the 1831 Goodwin House along Peachtree Road in Brookhaven.

column2: Fulton County formed from the western half of DeKalb
column3: divided along a perfectly straight and due north/south line down the middle (along which Moreland Avenue now runs). Until this time
column4: the growing city of Atlanta had been inside DeKalb. Atlanta grew because the city of Decatur did not want to become the railroad terminus in the 1830s
column5: thus a spot at the Thrasherville encampment in western DeKalb was picked to become Terminus and then Marthasville
column6: before becoming Atlanta a few years after its founding. North and southwest Fulton came from two other counties: Milton and southeast Campbell
column7: respectively. DeKalb once extended slightly further north to the Chattahoochee River
column8: but this strip was later given to Milton
column9: and is now the panhandle of Sandy Springs (though residents there identify with Dunwoody).During the Civil War
column10: much of the Battle of Atlanta took place in DeKalb.

column2: DeKalb was a mainly agricultural county
column3: but as the sprawl of the metropolitan Atlanta region expanded
column4: DeKalb became increasingly urbanized. Finished in 1969
column5: the eastern half of the Interstate 285 beltway
column7: ringed the northeastern and southern edges of the county
column8: placing most of it "inside the Perimeter" along with nearly all of Atlanta. Interstate 675 and Georgia 400 were originally planned to connect inside the Perimeter
column9: along with the Stone Mountain Freeway (U.S. Highway 78) connecting with the Downtown Connector (a co-signment of I-75/I-85) near Moreland Avenue
column10: destroying many neighborhoods in western DeKalb
column11: but community opposition in the early 1970s spared them this fate of urbanization
column12: although part of the proposed Stone Mountain Tollway later became the Freedom Parkway.  Only Interstate 20 and Interstate 85 were successfully built through the county. DeKalb also became one of only two counties to approve MARTA rapid transit in the 1970s; the county now contains the east and northeast heavy rail lines.

column2: more than 350 bus drivers for DeKalb County School District went on strike over low pay and poor working conditions
column3: resulting in seven bus drivers being fired.The DeKalb County seal was created in 1967
column4: by artist Jackson Bailey. The design is based on a passage from Aristotle in which a comparison is made between human progress and the relay race. The background landscape shows planted fields
column5: which is a tribute to DeKalb’s heritage as an agrarian community and Stone Mountain
column6: now recognized as Georgia’s most popular tourist attraction. The date of the county's founding
column8: is at the bottom of the seal.

column1: According to the U.S. Census Bureau
column2: the county has a total area of 271 square miles (700 km2)
column3: of which 268 square miles (690 km2) is land and 3.6 square miles (9.3 km2) (1.3%) is water. The county is located within the upper Piedmont region of the state.

column1: The county is crossed by the South River and numerous creeks
column2: including Nancy Creek
column3: Snapfinger Creek and two forks of Peachtree Creek. Peachtree Creek and Nancy Creek drain into the Chattahoochee River and eventually to the Gulf of Mexico. South River drains into the Ocmulgee River and ultimately into the Atlantic Ocean.

column1: The southern two-thirds of DeKalb County
column2: in a line from Druid Hills northeast to Tucker
column3: is located in the Upper Ocmulgee River sub-basin of the Altamaha River basin
column4: while the portion of the county north of that line is located in the Upper Chattahoochee River sub-basin of the ACF River Basin (Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint River Basin).Stone Mountain lies near the eastern border of the county. Soapstone Ridge
column6: was heavily quarried between 1400 and 100 B.C. and objects made from the soapstone have been found as far away as the Great Lakes.

column1: The DeKalb County 9/11 Memorial was dedicated on September 11
U.S. Marine and sculptor Curtis James Miller designed a memorial that is located in front of the Dekalb County Fire and Police Headquarters. The memorial pays homage to the 343 New York Firefighters
column2: 60 New York and Port Authority Police Officers and the more than 2800 civilian victims of the terrorist attacks in New York

column1: A piece of steel from one of the World Trade Center Towers in New York City is the centerpiece of this monument.

column2: along with many other counties in the Atlanta area
column3: DeKalb County has voted strongly Democratic in presidential elections
column4: while in the past it was more of a swing county
column5: voting Democratic and Republican an equal number of times from 1960 until 1988. Following the 2018 midterm elections
column6: there are no elected Republicans above the county level for the first time since the breakdown of the old Solid South.

column1: The portion of DeKalb County not within the city of Atlanta or the city of Decatur is served by DeKalb County School District (formerly DeKalb County School System). The Atlanta portion is served by Atlanta Public Schools. The Decatur portion is served by Decatur City School District.
